newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Telmex busy as stock rallies.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Telmex busy as stock rallies.

text.p: Telfonos de Mexico (Telmex) February 40 calls highlighted individual equity option trading Wednesday, attracting heavy volume as the shares broke through that strike price.
By 1400 CST/2000 GMT, the Telmex February 40 call traded a total of 13,610 contracts, the bulk of which crossed on the American Stock Exchange (AMEX).
Telmex options trade on the AMEX and the Chicago Board Options Exchange.
Telmex shares, extending Tuesday's rebound, were ahead 1-1/2 at 40-1/2, their session high.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Telmex was the most active issue, with more than 4.9 million shares changing hands. Consolidated volume topped 5.4 million.
On Tuesday, Telmex shares fell nearly a point before rebounding to close a point higher at 39.
The stock was up despite reporting disappointing earnings on Tuesday, American Depositary Receipt (ADR) traders said.
Harrison Roth, senior options strategist at Cowen & Co, said the stock's ability to crack the 40 strike price contributed to the heavy options volume at that strike.
The Telmex February 40 call had open interest of 24,537 contracts. More than 4,200 positions were closed on Tuesday.

"They've been liquidating those (positions) over the past four days, but there's still such a huge amount that it still was a concern," Joseph Sunderman, an analyst at Investment Research Institute in Cincinnati, said.
"Now the stock's been able to penetrate through that level, which is a healthy sign for the stock," he said.
He added that a key will be to see how much of Wednesday's volume is from positions being closed out as opposed to new positions being opened.
Sunderman said the Telmex February 40 calls continue to have one of the lowest volatilities among other Telmex options, which suggests most investors were exiting positions.
"Looking at other strikes, the March 40 (call) has a lot of volume and slightly higher implied volatility than the February 40," he said.
"We're also seeing a lot more trades going off near the ask, so that looks like new positions being opened."
The March 40 calls traded a total of 3,420 contracts.
In other action, an investor bought back DuPont Co July 90 calls and sold the January 1998 80 calls, Roth said.
Each of those two options traded 3,820 contracts. The investor bought back the July 90 calls at 22-1/4 and sold the LEAP (long term equity anticipation securities) January 80 call at 32-7/8.
Elsewhere, the Learning Co Inc February 15 put traded about 2,600 contracts and the March 12-1/2 traded about 2,860.
Roth said it appeared an investor bought the February 15 puts and sold the March 12-1/2s. The February 15s were trading at 4-7/8 and the March 12-1/2s at 2-1/2.
((-- G. Crawford, 312 408-8750/Email: derivatives@reuters.com))
